sequence.script: Last time, we concluded that once all of the major threats are developed in a game of connect 4, the result can be computed deterministically as a function of the positions of those threats.
We learned that the parity, or the even-ness or odd-ness of the row on which the threat lies, determines the result, but only in the case that there is a single column with threats on it.
Consider this example. Since everything other than the positions of the threats is superfluous, we will simply hide the disks which have been played.
We will also separate the columns to consider them individually.
However, we will be sure to leave all the threats where they are.
We now have a set of unadjoined columns. No need to worry about connecting 4 anymore. The players are just scrambling to get to a threat.
This model is a faithful representation of the game from which we took it, since as soon as a player claims a threat, that means they won the underlying game of connect 4.
So, we have reduced the endgame of connect 4 to this much simpler game of 'just-get-to-a-threat-as-soon-as-possible!'
In this view of the board, the 'dead space' is every piece which can be filled without getting to a threat or exposing it.
Let's see how the players might fill in the dead space.
This is important to consider since it tells us who is in the Zugzwang. That is, it tells us who will be the first person who will need to expose a threat.
And, in this case, it's Yellow.
In general, the player who is in Zugzwang is Red- that is, player 1, if the amount of dead space is even, or Yellow, AKA player 2, in the case that it is odd.

As a corollary, This means that any row which has no threat at all can simply be ignored. 6 pieces will be played in that column with no consequence, so it doesn't change the evenness or oddness of the total amount of dead space.
Knowing this, it is obvious why our parity rules from last time work when there is a single threat.
When the threat is odd- that is, it's on an odd row, such as this example here, there is an odd amount of dead space. That means Yellow is in the Zugzwang.
If the threat had been on an even row, there would have been an even amount of dead space, meaning Red would have been in Zugzwang.
And, to reiterate, adding an empty column won't change this result.
Both players will just climb up the column and it will be red's turn in Zugzwang once again. Adding an even amount of dead space doesn't change anything.
But as promised, it's time to generalize. There can be multiple rows which contain threats, and each row can contain multiple threats.
First, let's just set up a complex array of threats and see what happens.
The players begin by filling up the dead space, and there's an odd amount. So, Yellow is in the Zugzwang.
In other words, it's Yellow who gets to choose which threat to expose.
Of course, Yellow wouldn't expose a red threat, since Red would claim it, instantly winning the game.
That means Yellow will have to expose a Yellow threat, leaving us with these 3 options.
Let's say Yellow picks this one.
Yellow exposes the threat, Red blocks the threat, and the players fill in the newly discovered dead space above the threat.
But now, Yellow is once again in the Zugzwang! So, this didn't accomplish anything other than removing a Yellow threat from the board. Perhaps there was a better option?
Well, what about this threat?
Yellow exposes the threat, Red blocks the threat, but this time there is no dead space above the threat. Once again, Yellow is in the Zugzwang.
That leaves only one other option.
What if Yellow chooses to expose the leftmost threat?
Yellow exposes it, Red blocks it, and then, Yellow plays the single dead space above the threat. Now, Red is in the Zugzwang!
But... what actually just happened there?
Let's step back and consider the 3 threats which we just investigated.
In reality, we are not interested in the threat alone, rather the set of moves that get played in association with that threat.
This includes the threat itself, the spot below it which exposes the threat, and all of the dead space which will be played immediately after the threat is blocked.

Now it becomes clear why the leftmost threat gets Yellow out of the Zugzwang. It is the only threat which is composed of an odd number of spaces. Such a threat is said to exert control over the Zugzwang.
We always want to use threats which exert control over the Zugzwang before we expose other threats.
Ok, in that case, what should Red do here?
Let's start by identifying the threats.
This one has 5 spaces, so it exerts Zugzwang control.
This one has 3, so it does as well.
This one also has 3, but playing in it would reveal a yellow threat, which also exerts Zugzwang control! So, let's not let Yellow have it.
Finally, these 2 do not exert Zugzwang control.
So, it seems Red's best option is to take one of these two!
Because only they would kick the Zugzwang back to Yellow.
Now we have the foundation to understand why Yellow was winning in this example from last time.
The parity of the dead space was even, and furthermore, there was no threat that Red could give up to toggle the Zugzwang back to yellow.
Ok then, so are there any cases in which it is beneficial to expose or use a threat which does not exert Zugzwang control?
Here's a perfect example. The lower threat does not control the Zugzwang, but the top one does. Only by revealing the bottom one can Yellow arrive at the top threat and send the Zugzwang back to Red.
Here's a much more obvious example. In this case, Red wants to get to the major threat pair as soon as possible, thereby, instantly winning the game.
So, red will uncover the bottom threat, and then claim victory using the threat pair.
In both of these instances, we play the non-controlling threat to expose the upper threat. There's no harm in this as long as the two threats have the same color.
Therefore, since the threat will simply get trodded over, it can be ignored as dead space.

However, in a situation like this, the red non-controlling threat is the only thing preventing Yellow from reaching a threat pair. It may not help Red control the Zugzwang, but it is preventing a swift defeat.
For this reason, a threat which does not control the Zugzwang can be ignored if and only if there is a threat of the same color following it.

Now, we learned about threats which control and do not control the Zugzwang, but this threat pair can be considered as a separate kind of threat. Notice how the dead space above it can never be touched, since Yellow is guaranteed to win on the threat pair?
This 'terminal threat' has the property that nothing above it can ever be touched. Anything above it might as well not exist.
The same can be said of a threat held by both players. This threat is terminal- whoever touches it wins, so there's no getting above it.
This yellow threat might as well not exist. The result would be identical.
Let's look at one other type of threat which we have neglected until now.
This threat chain here actually works just like a normal threat.
The chained threats above the bottom one will be played in the same way that players fill the dead space above a threat. So, the chain doesn't do anything special.
And, since it has an even amount of spaces, it does not exert Zugzwang control.
So, we can simply imagine that the chained threats are absent.
Ok, let's see another example to see how we can use all of this.
Here are the existing threats. Let's start by simplifying columns with terminal threats.
On the left, the red-and-yellow threat is a terminal, so we can simply remove everything above it.
The paired yellow threat one column over is also a terminal, so we can remove everything above it too.
The chained threat in the 6th column can be simplified by ignoring the chain.
The rightmost threat pair belongs to red- there's no way that Yellow could get to the upper threat without Red having gotten the bottom one.
We are also safe to ignore these two red threats which exert no control over the Zugzwang, since there is another red threat above each one.
The same is true of this yellow non-controlling threat.
Ok, this looks a lot more manageable! Can you tell how this game will proceed?
Red is in the Zugzwang, since there is an even amount of dead space.
Red will start by toggling the Zugzwang like so.
Yellow will then return the favor.
Now red once more.
Followed by Yellow once more!
At this point, Red has no other option but to cede a terminal threat to Yellow, thereby forfeiting.

Ok, let's take a step back. We have now taxonomized all threats into Zugzwang-controlling threats (marked with a Z,) non-controlling threats (marked with a zero,) and terminal threats (marked with a hash.)
We can label these different threat types in a separate diagram like so.
With the diagram on the bottom, we abstract away all of the unnecessary details and boil down this particular endgame to its fundamental structure.
Let's watch the players play this same game over, but track what happens as they play hot-potato with the Zugzwang.
Red sent the Zugzwang to Yellow first like this, expending a Zugzwang-controlling threat.
Yellow sent the Zugzwang back to red by using the threat on the sixth column.
Red handed it back over again.
And now Yellow.
Now Red is clearly going to lose, because no remaining red threats can toggle the Zugzwang, so Red will end up revealing a yellow threat.
Let's consider a yet more perplexing case, this time looking only at the diagram.

Red's in the Zugzwang. Which threat should Red expose first? There turns out to be a very simple answer for determining this in any situation. The trick is to greedily take whichever Zugzwang-controlling threat has the fewest opponent Zugzwang-controlling threats immediately above it.
In this case, that's the bottom-left threat, since there is no yellow threat immediately above it- there is another red threat there.
Now, Yellow would expose the only immediately available threat.
Red now takes the second-column threat, since it only has one yellow threat stacked immediately above it.
Yellow now takes the third-column threat, since it has the smallest red stack above it.
Now red...
And yellow...
And red...
Now there are no more exposable Yellow threats left, so Yellow exposes a Red threat and loses.
I'll leave it as an open puzzle for you to demonstrate why the greedy algorithm always works here.

It's also worth noting that once you have this threat diagram, there are yet further simplifications that can be made involving terminal and non-controlling threats, but we won't go into them here. Understanding what we've covered so far is more than sufficient to derive the win conditions of the standard board size.
Now that our endgame theory is basically complete, let's see how to actually apply this, by categorizing some common threat patterns.

Lucky for us, I've sort of been lying throughout this video. Threat combinations as complex as the ones we saw earlier are totally impossible. It could happen on a bigger board size, so it's good to understand.
But on a traditional board size, there can't even be this many threats. After all, there are only two pieces played. We're not even in the endgame.

In practice, one or two columns with threats are common to see, but 3 or more is increasingly rare. Since our parity mechanics explain the one-column case, let's determine the win conditions for two threatened columns.
When two yellow threats with nothing below them are both on even rows, or both on odd rows, then Yellow will win. Red's in the Zugzwang and can't toggle it.
If Red has two threats with one even and one odd, then Red wins by the same reasoning.
What about if each player has a Zugzwang-controlling threat? It's red's move.
It's a tie!
If we give Red 2 Zugzwang-controlling threats, that will be sufficient to overpower Yellow, who is in the Zugzwang to begin with.
Flipping around the position, we get a tie. Not a yellow win- yellow is disadvantaged by being in the Zugzwang from the start.
Since a second and fifth row threatened column exerts Zugzwang control twice, yet third and sixth rows exerts it only once, Red wins this one since Yellow starts in the Zugzwang.
If we flip it around, the game ends as a tie.

While there are an unending amount of different ways that columns can be threatened, by using the tools of reduction and abstraction which we learned here, it can be rather easily determined who is to win, even on arbitrarily large board sizes where we haven't memorized the win conditions.

scenes.script: What we have done here was no mean feat- we have effectively and absolutely solved the endgame. Now the task is to work backwards. Is there a way that we can comparably reduce the midgame? The answer is, in many cases, yes. Stay tuned, because we will start to get a feeling of the shape and space of certain weakly solved subtrees of Connect 4.
